content.description: Warm up the left hammy for some heel hooking pump fun through big moves that lead to a stopper crux. As you pull through the face just above the lip of the roof, holds will disappear except for the perfect right hand sloper with just enough bite to hold on and build your feet. Balance up before clipping the 4th bolt and find a pretty good rest. Hold on for incredible climbing in the upper section that will pump you off if you're not ready.

This one's good. Big Holds, Small Holds, Steep, Big Holds, Still Steep, Big Move, Little Roof, Classic Iron Plates, Anchors. That's it in a nutshell. But a climb this good deserves a word or two more: amazing rock, memorable moves, and a sustained, steep wall with a it-ain't-over punch at the end. One climber suggested it might be the best 5.12 in Virginia. Who's to say, but this is about as good as gets for flowing, pumpy moves over steep southeastern sandstone. (Edit: ZLH)

Begin on big holds in steep terrain up to about the third bolt. Smaller rails to a rest leads into the upper crux. Pull the roof and finish on fun/easy (except the last two moves) climbing to the chains.
content.location: Route Left of the corner that moves through rippled rock at third bolt.

content.description: Consistently steep movement begins on a seam that leads to your first jug near the first bolt. Follow a line of jugs and long moves (and run-outs).  Pray those love handles haven't sagged into slopers and travel the final 8 feet into the glorious iron plates and a wonderful view.  (Don't traverse to clip the Anchors  of "Breaking Brad" which may be tempting if you're pumped)
content.location: This route begins on an obvious seam central to the steep part of the lodges wall.

content.description: A few easy moves leads to a hard roof pull and great face climbing through beautiful rock and orange lichen.  Keep it together for a bit of a runout to the top.
content.location: Left side of the Steep section bolt line is right of a seam and through roof pillows.

content.description: Delicately ascend a remarkably thin and large potato chip to the first bolt and then use small feet and good hands to make it to the anchors and another fantastic view.
content.location: Onces at lodges crag follow the wall all the way climber's left.  Just before it goes around the corner and gets a little chossy you should find the potato chip hold beneath the first bolt.

content.description: Really pretty sandstone face climbing, unfortunately hidden behind a tree.
content.location: After walking up the short scramble towards lodges, you'll walk down hill on some rock stairs, and back up towards the cliff.  Look for this short bolted line behind a tree close to the cliff.
route in the apetheather.  Starts out a 4 foot horizontal roof.  This route is flanked by dripping wet streaks on both the left and right but the route itself stays dry nearly all the time.

climbs.name: Friends Don't Let Friend's Climb Fat

content.description: A fun and pumpy 5.11 on great rock. Some little roof pulls keep you hoppin', and patina holds at the end are memorable. A quality line in its own right, and a good forearm fattener for the harder routes nearby.
Route on left side of cave/steep section. A small bulge pull leads to lower angled climbing with some neat mantle moves.
content.location: Left side of steep section at lodges wall.

content.description: Climb up a seam to a big hole in the wall.  Moderate face climbing (that is still really dirty) leads to the top.
content.location: Far left of lodges wall.  Right of "handle with care"

content.description: Pumpy climbing that leads to a thin crux.
Fun start and stop bouldering through moderately steep terrain lead to a brutal boulder crux to gain the clipping chains at the top.  The final boulder is likely v8 ish.  Go get it if you can.
content.location: Left of the 11b.   Begins low angle for 3 bolts before pulling the roof.

content.description: Sunny, about a 10 minute hike beneath the lodges.  No trail yet.  Some routes will seep for about a day after a rain or snow melt.
